ABOUT ME


I am a PhD student in the Department of Economics, at the University of Pittsburgh.

I specialize in public, urban, behavioral, and political economy. My main research interests focus on belief formation, equalibrium selection, and spatial sorting, and their social and political impacts and economic drivers.



Current

Herding to the Polls

tl;dr. Voters condition their turnout decision on the political preferences of their neighbors.


Current

The Small Sort

tl;dr. Voters have a preference for living near politically aligned neighbors.


Current

The Great Electoral Divergence

tl;dr. The changing urban wage gradient has led to increasinly partisan cities.


Current

Equilibrium Selection Over Dynamic Strategies

tl;dr.


Current

Tiebout and the City

tl;dr.
